info.game_comments:
2004-A Kids Week game 5.
From Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: Iodine gas is this color associated with royalty & with a dinosaur who loves you

(2, 1).clue: You want to break ties in the U.S. Senate, so use recess to study hard & become VP like this man is today

(3, 1).clue: In the title of a Dr. Seuss book, it's served with "Green Eggs"

(4, 1).clue: "Pop" is on this 'N Sync album whose title refers ironically to the band's fame

(5, 1).clue: First reached in 1911, it's the point in Antarctica through which the Earth's axis passes

(6, 1).clue: Frau & fraulein are terms for women in this language

(1, 2).clue: When you see starlight, star bright, know it's from the star burning this gas, whose symbol is H

(2, 2).clue: Head to the art room & paint a masterpiece like the 16th century "Mona Lisa" by this man

(3, 2).clue: This character dresses his dog like a reindeer & steals Christmas from Who-ville

(4, 2).clue: You'll understand her songs, like "Ironic" & "Hands Clean", when you're older & more bitter

(5, 2).clue: The crab-eater type of this, like the one seen here, is a common sight in Antarctica

(6, 2).clue: Literally meaning "to God", it's how you say good-bye in Spanish

(1, 3).clue: The air that we breathe is mostly not oxygen but this gas, N

(2, 3).clue: Impress the gym coach; practice your spin technique for tossing a 16-pound metal ball in this Olympic event

(3, 3).clue: This kind Seuss elephant "Hears a Who" & also "Hatches the Egg"

(4, 3).clue: These "Who Let The Dogs Out?" hitmakers come, logically enough, from the Bahamas

(5, 3).clue: 2 species of these birds that inhabit Antarctica are the adelie & the emperor

(6, 3).clue: If you're in a store in Spain & you see a sign over a door saying "Salida", it means this

(1, 4).clue: Indium is an element in the family of this popular wrap metal

(2, 4).clue: Go to metal shop & make a scale model of this Parisian landmark that cost over $1 million to build from 1887 to 1889

(3, 4).clue: This Dr. Seuss book has been published in Spanish as "El Gato Ensombrerado"

(4, 4).clue: With spiky hair & names like Sid Vicious, this style of rock music shocked people in the '70s

(1, 5).clue: You're very busy if you have too many bars of this element, Fe, in the fire

(2, 5).clue: Dash off a major piece of literature like this 1852 Harriet Beecher Stowe novel

(3, 5).clue: This turtle king stacks up all the other turtles to build a towering throne only to fall down from the top

(4, 5).clue: Despite their name, at least 1 member of this band has already hit 20:"That is how we want it /Floorfiller /That is how we need it"

(1, 1).clue: It flows through Washington, D.C. & on past Mount Vernon

(2, 1).clue: This imaginary creature takes away the tooth you leave under your pillow & replaces it with money

(3, 1).clue: According to the Declaration of Independence, "All men are created" this way

(4, 1).clue: Famous professionals in this sport include David Duval & Annika Sorenstam

(5, 1).clue: In 2003 the Oregon Children's Theatre premiered a play about this woman who hit the trail with Lewis & Clark

(1, 2).clue: The Lincoln & Holland tunnels let cars travel from Manhattan to New Jersey under this river

(2, 2).clue: Using Du Pont technology, the first one of these with synthetic bristles was introduced in 1938

(3, 2).clue: It completes a quote from Thomas Palmer in 1840: "If at first you don't succeed..."
(3, 2).correct response: try, try again (try and try again accepted)

(4, 2).clue: Dan Marino & Joe Montana will long be remembered as great offensive players in this sport

(5, 2).clue: Several different musicals have been based on Margery Williams' tale about this "Velveteen" creature

(6, 2).clue: You may want to D/L some files to your desktop, meaning this

(1, 3).clue: This river of the Pacific Northwest provides much of the boundary between Washington & Oregon

(2, 3).clue: These large mammals are divided into 2 main groups, toothed & baleen

(3, 3).clue: This Dickens guy says, "Every idiot who" says, "Merry Christmas... should be boiled with his own pudding"

(4, 3).clue: It's the baseball position played by Hideo Nomo & Curt Schilling

(5, 3).clue: In the play "True History and Real Adventures", kids search for the truth about this "calamitous" Wild West gal

(6, 3).clue: If you have an "RFI", you have a "request for" this

(1, 4).clue: The Falls of Saint Anthony stop this mighty river from being navigable north of St. Paul, Minnesota

(2, 4).clue: Covered by enamel, this visible part of a tooth sounds like something a king wears

(3, 4).clue: Romeo sighs, "O! that I were" one of these "upon that hand, that I might touch" that "cheek"

(4, 4).clue: Secretariat, Affirmed & Seattle Slew have all been Triple Crown winners in this sport

(5, 4).clue: Arnold Lobel's books for kids inspired the musical "A Year with Frog and" this other amphibian

(1, 5).clue: This river bisects the state of South Dakota from north to south

(2, 5).clue: Of the genus Smilodon, it's the extinct tiger seen here

(3, 5).clue: E.M. Forster proposed "Two cheers for" this system of government that "admits variety &... permits criticism"

(4, 5).clue: This 7-foot San Antonio Spur, the 2003 NBA finals MVP, grew up in the U.S. Virgin Islands

(5, 5).clue: You weren't even born when this musical about a spooky guy in an opera house debuted on Broadway in 1988

(0, 0).clue: 2 of the 4 states whose names start & end with the same letter
